repnme.cdata!:
Liberia - Emergency Senior Executive
            Service Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Emergency Senior
            Executive Service Project for Liberia were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately satisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was moderate, the Bank performance was
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was moderately
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: simple and
            relatively inexpensive projects are low risk and can deliver
            high impact results in low capacity fragile environments.
            They are easy to supervise, and could be effective in
            rallying around donors in difficult contexts immediately
            after conflict while providing immediate capacity needed to
            undertake other important reconstruction projects. The
            Senior Executive Service (SES) operation was designed with
            two straight forward components, with a small budget. For a
            country emerging from conflict, and with very little
            implementation capacity, a multi-donor approach not only
            provided the requisite financial support for the project,
            but also helped support coordinated and collaborative
            implementation supervision. Countries in post conflict
            situations, characterized by complete institutional
            collapse, should consider carefully the level of ambition of
            capacity initiatives, including undertaking a level of
            analysis of lessons learned from previous attempts on the
            provision of 'surge capacity'. The program will,
            most likely, be susceptible to local capacity challenges.
            Short term technical assistance should be factored into the
            design and deployed early during the program implementation,
            and should maintain continuous support and oversight.
            Program such SES are not always controversial, especially
            when applied in low capacity environments. Recruiting former
            high profile political appointees for assignments in their
            former organizations requires special consideration. Handled
            poorly, it can engender hostility or fear. Handled well, the
            SES can bring valuable institutional memory to support
            government operations after the emergency period. Matching
            the skills and capabilities of program 'recruits'
            into the recipient institutions requires detailed
            'matching-making' and a carefully managed
            integration/support process (again this can come from
            specialized technical assistance).

14148893.projn:
LR-Emergency Senior Executive Service
            Project (Esesp) -- P109195

repnme.cdata!:
Liberia - Senior Executive Service Project
            : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the Senior
            Executive Service Project for Liberia is to provide the
            senior managerial and professional staff to key ministries,
            to increase high level capacity and lead reform and
            restructuring for better policy making, regulation and
            improved service delivering. The extension is necessary to
            extend the closing date of the project from December 31,
            2010 to June 30, 2011; and to re-allocate the sum of
            US$60,000 from the recurrent costs expenditure category of
            the project to goods, consultancy and training expenditure
            category. This extension will give the recipient the
            opportunity to continue to benefit from the services of the
            Senior Executive Service (SES) professionals for an
            additional period of six months. This extra time will help
            to compensate for the delays in implementation suffered as a
            result of weak project management capacity at the beginning
            of the project. This capacity issue has since been addressed
            by the replacement of the national project coordinator, with
            a more experienced project manager. None of the changes will
            have a major effect on the original economic, financial,
            technical, or social aspects of the project as appraised;
            nor will they raise the environmental category of the
            project or trigger new safeguard policies. A re-appraisal
            will therefore not be needed. Finally, the changes will
            involve no exceptions to bank policy.

0.cdata!:
Bid, cells, Contract Award, Documents,
            Inspection, Loan, Procurement, Procurement Plan, video,
            video conferencing

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the
            Emergency Senior Executive Service Project (ESESP) is to
            provide Government with the immediate assistance needed to
            develop a cadre of technical and managerial public servants
            who are well motivated to both meet immediate high level
            capacity needs and help transform the civil service into a
            more professional, effective and accountable institution of
            the Government of Liberia. The project has two components
            with the first being the recruitment of members for the
            Senior Executive Service (SES) scheme which involves the
            recruitment of a minimum of 100 SES members. A total of 21
            positions will be recruited as the first wave of
            recruitment. The second component is for the management of
            the SES scheme. This component would be used to procure
            basic furniture and office equipment to support and
            strengthen the capacity of Civil Service Agency (CSA) as the
            oversight civil service institution to eventually manage the
            SES program at the end of the project. In addition, the
            component will be used to pay for travel and relocation
            expenses, workshops and seminars to be organized on the SES
            scheme, exit package, and monitoring and evaluation of the scheme.
